title: I paid for a procedure in advance at my dental office and two weeks later they were closed due to bankruptcy. Can I sue?
question: My mother paid her dental office $1500 in advance for a dental implant. Two weeks later the office was closed down due to bankruptcy. Can we sue the office?
answers: While the bankruptcy is pending you cannot sue them. You should get notice from the court that you are a creditor. You will probably have to file a proof of claim form to have any chance of getting your money back. Since you are an unsecured creditor, you are last in line. I would either hire counsel, which may be expensive, given your small debt, or wait and file a proof of claim form, if you are listed as a creditor. I am not suggesting that $1500 is a small amount. However, depending on his debts, it may not get paid or only a small sum may get paid back.

Unfortunately, there is a stay in the Bankruptcy Court that prevents you from suing. However, you will get a creditors claim mailed to you that you can make your claim. It also sounds to me like this is border line fraud. The Dental Office would have known they were going to file bankruptcy in all likelihood, and consequently it would be well worth finding the person to talk to at the Dental Office to get this back. Further, you can deal with this through the State Licensing Board which can be a pretty good hammer to help you get your money back.
You will have to make a claim in the bankruptcy proceeding. You should contact a local bankruptcy lawyer for more information.

Trying to collect money from someone who has declared bankruptcy is a violation of the automatic stay, and will cause you all kinds of problems. Your best bet is to bring the claim against the bankruptcy estate. If you can successfully argue that the money was fraudulently obtained (they took it never intending to provide services and knowing that they were going out of business) it may be non-dischargeable.

No. Once a debtor files any type of bankruptcy, the debtor is afforded an automatic stay. This means that no creditor may take or continue an action against a creditor without requesting that the bankruptcy court give the creditor permission to do so (or lift the stay).
You can make a claim against the bankruptcy estate, but all lawsuits are stayed if he has already filed and named your mother as a potential creditor.
